history.content: It’s important to note that getting a PhD doesn’t really make the ceiling higher, it just changes what type of work you are able to do. I think what you’re looking for a masters degree based on what you want. Masters make the same (if not more) than PhDs and if you’re thinking of going into management (I assume that’s what you mean by career ceiling) then that’s what you want. You can continue your current research since you need to write a masters thesis, but you’ll only be committing to 2 years instead of 6.

children.subject: FYI I've heard the 5th year MS has gotten much more competitive just over the past cycle and that having a research advisor sign off is no longer sufficient.

That might be the case, but I'd argue that, for an applicant with something like a 3.7 GPA and solid but not exceptional research experience, it remains far easier to get into than, say, an MS program at Stanford.

Also, if you find yourself leaning more towards doing a PhD, you can mention your fifth year MS application to UC Berkeley on applications to prestigious fellowships like the NSF GRFP or NDSEG Fellowship. At that point, it might be worthwhile to just throw in a few PhD applications to other schools, but governmental fellowships are an even bigger prize than elite PhD admissions results, in my opinion. If you can manage to secure NSF or NDSEG (or NSERC for Canadians, other countries probably have their own programs), the other stuff follows remarkably simply. I mention this chiefly because UC Berkeley professors are really good at writing what governmental agencies want to hear, and, depending on how closely tied your lab is to NSF and/or DARPA, this can really help your odds for these fellowships (and PhD admissions as a result). It's also worth noting that NSF and NDSEG allow an unlimited number of applications from undergrads, and usually only one from matriculated graduate students (including fifth year MS students).

Just to add on to the previous answer, I think the fifth year master's here might be a good way for you to continue with your current research while leaving paths to both industry and academia open. Admission is mostly conditional on having a research adviser in EECS willing to allow you to (continue to) do research in their lab, so you might have that covered already. I know plenty of people who have used this program to get good positions in industry and/or build their CVs for admission to competitive PhD programs (e.g. Stanford, Berkeley). As an added bonus, graduate tuition is lower than undergraduate tuition (significantly so for out-of-state students), so doing this would make a lot more sense than paying "full-freight" at another school, in my opinion.

history.content:
Hey everyone, so I'm currently still a sophomore and hence all the issues that I'm about to describe might just be meaningless worries in my head since I lack experience or perspective, but I had a few questions I was hoping this community could help me with.

For this whole semester, I've been constantly conflicted about whether I want to pursue a PhD in CS or not. As someone who has been conducting research for approx. a year, I really like the kind of research I'm doing and would love to continue with it. However, I've never really desired to go into academia so even if I do pursue a PhD I would like to move into industry and work on interesting problems in industrial research labs. However, I'm not sure whether I want to commit the ~6 years a PhD generally requires and if I would still enjoy similar research when I have to do it for such a long period of time. The benefit, of course, is that it would open doors for me to do more interesting, challenging work.

In comparison, the other option is that I decide to directly enter industry and start working. It appeals to me because I would be able to immediately start earning and I also found my last internship pretty fun. The downside, however, is that I may be restricting myself to work that may not be as interesting or challenging. Moreover, a few years down the road, I may be stuck on the progression ladder since lacking a better qualification than a Bachelors may not allow me to go for those specialized roles. 

Hence, could anybody who's been through such a situation provide some guidance or tips? In general, would a Master's be a good middle ground (although I've heard that it doesn't really help that much over just a Bachelors)?  Do you think it's worth it to commit those 6 years in such a case?
history.subject: Any way to raise your max career ceiling without committing ~6 yr for a PhD?
